bAMWOx-s3.memHandModelNotes:
Not sure what Matt E's modeling methods were trying to get at with focalsum and the 1km moving window.  Is it a 1km2 moving window, i.e. ~ 1111 cells?  If so, his model selects areas with <98 % in each selected habitat, adds them together, then uses as a mask.  Riiter's "perforated forest" may be a good choice for this species.

I think Matt was using a 5x6 window (not 1km2) and selecting at least ~80% open (>24 cells of FOCALSUM) and at least ~87% forested (>26 cells of FOCALSUM).  I tested how this would compare to selecting open/forest edge with a 250m ecotone. It comes out about the same if you consider all types of forest and open (and provided I'm understanding Matt's model correctly). If both models are limited to the map units selected, it should come out to something similar. MJR 7dec06.

habitat_description:
Within the northeast region, the American woodcock is a year-round (breeding and wintering) resident along the Atlantic coastal plain from Delaware south to North Carolina. In the remainder of the northeast region, the American woodcock is present in summer (breeding) only (see NE summer model)(Keppie and Whiting 1994; NatureServe 2009).

Breeding habitat of the American woodcock is closely associated with young second-growth hardwoods and other early successional habitats (NatureServe 2009). Forest habitats with openings, such as young forest and abandoned farmland with mixed forest are ideal (Keppie and Whiting 1994). Forest openings and old fields provide display areas for males as grasses, herbaceous cover, and low shrubs are replaced by young trees (Keppie and Whiting 1994). 

The American woodcock nests in young, open, second-growth deciduous forests with well-drained soils, and is more abundant in open forest than in denser deciduous sapling or conifer cover. Nesting habitat is geographically varied, and includes drier woodland sites, young open woodlands, low shrubby cover, old fields, tall herbage bordering clearings, thickets, scrub oaks or pines, open woodland with dead leaf cover on ground, and flat bottomlands near water. High shrub stem density and presence of edge habitat may be important in nest site selection in some areas (NatureServe 2009).

Wintering habitats are similar to the breeding habitats described above, but include more man-made habitas (e.g., rice fields, agricultural lands), and are not limited to early-successional forest types (Keppie and Whiting 1994; NatureServe 2009). In winter, the American woodcock will utilize a wider variety of forest types, including bottomland hardwoods, upland mixed pine-hardwoods, and mature longleaf pine that has been recently burned (Keppie and Whiting 1994). Occassionally, the species will also utilize coastal meadows (NatureServe 2009). C. Maynard, 2feb10.
